indicators.justification:
Data on air Emission Accounts by industry and type of emission can be found at Statistics Denmark. The accounts can be used for climate and environmental-economic analysis. The emission accounts are developed for 1990 and onwards according to EEA, System of Environmental Economic Accounting, which is a statistical standard published by the UN and several other international organizations provides the "State of the art" for Green National Accounts. The statistics is part of the Environmental-Economic Accounts for Denmark (Green National Accounts).



(1) Statistics Denmark, "Air Emission Accounts by industry and type of emission", 2021, https://www.statbank.dk/MRU1

(2) Statistics Denmark, "Bridge table by bridging items and type of emission", 2021, https://www.statbank.dk/MRO1

evidence.title: Air Emission Accounts by industry and type of emission
Bridge table by bridging items and type of emission

indicators.justification:
Simple access to beneficial ownership and company information is online available at datacvr.virk.dk, where API access is also described. After registration and with technical skills is it possible to download data via the API.

indicators.justification:
Both the register of cause of death and birth are managed by Sundhedsdatastyrelsen and linked to the comprehensive civil registration system. Open statistical data on cause of death and birth can be found at eSundhed and at Statistics Denmark.

(1) Eurostat, "Causes of death statistics", 2021, https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php?title=Causes_of_death_statistics

(2) Sundhedsdatastyrelsen, "Dokumentation af registre - Dødsårsagsregisteret", 2017: https://www.esundhed.dk/Dokumentation/DocumentationExtended?id=17

(3) Sundhedsdatastyrelsen, "Dødsårsagsregisteret", 2012-: https://www.esundhed.dk/Registre/Doedsaarsagsregisteret

(4) Sundhedsdatastyrelsen, "Det Mediciske Fødselsregister", 1973-: https://www.esundhed.dk/Registre/Det-medicinske-foedselsregister

(5) Statistics Denmark, "Births", 2021: https://www.dst.dk/en/Statistik/emner/befolkning-og-valg/foedsler/foedsler

(6) Statistics Denmark, "Deaths", 2021: https://www.dst.dk/en/Statistik/emner/befolkning-og-valg/doedsfald-og-middellevetid/doedsfald

(7) EU Commission, "Commission Regulation (EU) No 328/2011 of 5 April 2011 implementing Regulation (EC) No 1338/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council on Community statistics on public health and health and safety at work, as regards statistics on causes of death", 2011: https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/ALL/?uri=CELEX%3A32011R0328

Birth information includes data about sex and/or assigned gender of child, gestational age, and birth weight.
Birth information includes data about live-birth order and interval between last and previous live births to mother.
Birth information includes data about place of occurrence, place of usual residence of mother, and month of occurrence.
Birth information includes data about place of registration and month of registration.
Birth information includes data about age, educational attainment, and ethnic and/or national group of mother.
Birth information includes data about age of father and place of usual residence.
Birth information includes data about site of delivery, attendant at birth, and month in which prenatal care began.

indicators.justification:
The covid-related health care information is published by Statens Serum Institute. They have collected relevant numbers at their website and present data in dashboards and as downloadable files.

Published data contains information on number of covid-related patients, the availability of regular beds and ICU beds are not static. The capacity is monitored in weekly reports.

(1) Statens Serum Institut, "Ugentlige opgørelser med overvågningsdata", 2021: https://covid19.ssi.dk/overvagningsdata/ugentlige-opgorelser-med-overvaagningsdata

(2) Statens Serum Institut, "Covid-19 Danmark", 2021: https://experience.arcgis.com/experience/aa41b29149f24e20a4007a0c4e13db1d

(3) Sundhedsstyrelsen, "Sygehusdrift", 2021: https://www.sst.dk/da/corona/Sundheds-og-aeldresektoren/Sygehusdrift

(4) Statens Serum Institut, "Coronatal", 2021: https://www.sst.dk/da/corona/COVID-19-og-ny-coronavirus/Coronatal

indicators.justification:
The Danish Health Authority has provided daily data on COVID-19 vaccination during the pandemic. Information is available as charts, key figures and downloadable data.

(2) Statens Serum Institut, "Statens Serum Institut - Vaccination" https://experience.arcgis.com/experience/1c7ff08f6cef4e2784df7532d16312f1

The data includes information about the sex and/or gender of the people who have been vaccinated.

The data includes information about membership in a marginalized population among the people who have been vaccinated.
The data includes information about vaccination for residents of long-term care facilities.
The data includes information about vaccination for residents of prisons and jails.

indicators.justification:
Regulations provides detailed information on the collection and organization of government budget and spending. These data are published in details - even though information at transaction level is not - by multiple authoritative sources as the Agency for Public Finance and Management and Statistics Denmark. But it has not been possible to find a regulation or law that requires publication or the form of publication. 

(1) Agency for Public Finance and Management, "Finanslovsdatabasen", 2021, https://www.oes-cs.dk/olapdatabase/finanslov/index.cgi

(2) Agency for Public Finance and Management, "Regnskabsdatabasen", 2021, https://www.oes-cs.dk/olapdatabase/regnskab/index.cgi

(3) Statistics Denmark, "National accounts and finances", 2021, https://www.statbank.dk/statbank5a/SelectTable/Omrade0.asp?SubjectCode=14&PLanguage=1

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
There is structured data available on the executive budget proposal in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data available on amended budgets (when applicable) or amendments of the enacted budget.
There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.
Data is disaggregated by cross-cutting programs, or issues such as SDGs, climate action, gender budgeting, etc,
The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.
Data is timely and updated.
Historical data is available that allows users to track change over time.
Data is provided in machine-readable format(s)
The machine-readable dataset is available as a whole

indicators.justification:
Data on campaign and party finance is only sparsely available in Denmark. Political parties are required to publish yearly accounts but with few requirements to the level of details. Donations to political parties can be held anonymous if below a threshold of 20.000 DKK. For donations above this threshold, the name of the donor shall be published but not the exact amount given. The accounts of the political parties are published at the Parliament website in a PDF-file.

(1) Folketinget, "Gruppestøtte og regnskaber", 2021, https://www.ft.dk/da/partier/om-politiske-partier/gruppestoette-og-regnskaber

(2) Retsinformation, "Partistøtteloven", 2017, https://www.retsinformation.dk/eli/lta/2017/973

(3) Retsinformation, "Partiregnskabsloven", 2019, https://www.retsinformation.dk/eli/lta/2019/139

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?

indicators.justification:
The procurement practice is party regulated by EU rules. Tenders that qualify as EU tenders are published at the EU tender portal TED. Non-EU tenders are in many cases described at a national portal for tenders.

SKI a not-for-profit organization works to develop better public procurement framework agreements. These framework agreements are published at SKI's website.

indicators.justification:
Initiatives both in the Digital Strategy, the "fælles­offentlige digitale arkitektur" and "Grunddataprogrammet" (basic data program) supports the reuse of government data. Also a partnership is established to help private reuse of open government data.

indicators.justification:
Both initiatives in the Digital Strategy, the "fælles­offentlige digitale arkitektur" and "Grunddataprogrammet" (basic data program) supports the reuse of government data. Also a partnership is established to help private reuse of open government data. None of these are solely open government data initiatives, but open data is an important element.



(1) The Government, Local Government Denmark and Danish Regions, "Digital Strategy", 2016-2020, 
https://digst.dk/media/16165/ds_singlepage_uk_web.pdf

(2) Den fællesoffentlige rammearkitektur, "Referencearkitektur for deling af data og dokumenter", 2021, https://arkitektur.digst.dk/referencearkitektur-deling-af-data-og-dokumenter-0

evidence.title: Referencearkitektur for deling af data og dokumenter

There is a government team in place supporting open data activities.
There is an allocated budget for open data activities.
There is a well-maintained open data portal.
There is guidance and support for government publication of open data.
Senior political leaders back the open data initiative.

responses.response_text: The open data initiative covers only a limited part of the national government, but there are similar initiatives for many other parts of government.
responses.subquestion_text: How widely does this, or similar, open data initiatives apply?

indicators.justification:
There are multiple initiatives and partnerships involving "Local Government Denmark" (KL) the association of the 98 Danish municipalities and "Danish Regions" the association of the 5 Danish regions. Not all the municipalities has the capacities themselves, especially the smaller municipalities lacks own expert data capacities.

indicators.justification:
Assessed training is possible to attend for all public servants but are not mandatory and requires the consent of the relevant manager.

indicators.justification:
The different political integrity datasets identified are not structured for interoperability.
Names of the political parties can be used as identifier. Other names in data can be used as well but can't function as unique identifiers. This leaves the datasets with minimal consistency.

(1) Folketinget, "Gruppestøtte og regnskaber", 2021, https://www.ft.dk/da/partier/om-politiske-partier/gruppestoette-og-regnskaber

(2) The Government, "CVs and economic interests of ministers", 2021, https://www.regeringen.dk/ministrene/

(3) Folketinget, "Economic interest of MPs", 2021, https://www.ft.dk/da/medlemmer/hverv-og-oekonomiske-interesser

(4) Civilstyrelsen, "Høringsportalen", 2021, https://hoeringsportalen.dk/

responses.response_text: The datasets do not share common identifiers.
responses.subquestion_text: There is evidence that datasets share common identifiers.
The key datasets for this theme share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The different political integrity datasets use common identifiers for public officials.
Lobbying data and political finance data share common identifiers for lobbyist clients and party and campaign donors.
Lobbying registers and public consultation data use common identifiers for regulations.
Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public finance modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

responses.response_text: There is minimal consistency; at least one category of identifiers is consistent across two datasets.
responses.subquestion_text: To what degree do the datasets associated with this theme use consistent identifiers and identification systems for elements that appear in more than one dataset?

indicators.justification:
Collecting and publishing beneficial ownership data on companies is regulated by law. Ownership of companies are searchable and can be accessed through an API.

The Web Accessibility Act ("Lov om webtilgængelighed") presents principles and techniques to be used on public sector websites and applications to insure accessibility. The law implements the EU directive on the accessibility of the websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies.

indicators.justification:
Multiple rules represents a framework for consistent data management and publication. The Basic Data Program (Grunddataprogrammet) identifies central data sets and provides a system to distribution of data. A common architecture for public sector IT set standards and presents guidelines for data management and publication within the public sector.

(1) Danish Agency for Digitisation, "Basic data", 2021:
https://en.digst.dk/data-and-it-architecture/basic-data/

There are minimum standards for metadata when government data is catalogued or published.
There is a standardised process for publishing and updating published government data.
There are technical standards, including common data models, codelists, and identifiers for management and publication of government data.
There are clearly documented quality control processes for government data.
There are clearly documented processes for soliciting and integrating feedback from external users to improve data quality.

responses.response_text: The data management approaches assessed apply to a limited number of departments or localities, but similar approaches are present across much of the public sector.

indicators.justification:
A framework for data sharing is described in the Danish PSI-law, also name reuse of public data ("Videreanvendelse af offentlige data"). The law implements the EU directive on open data and the re-use of public sector information.

indicators.justification:
The Public Accounts Committee published a report in 2019 on the state of open government data in Denmark: 

The implementation of the PSI-act in Danish law is the only legal framework in regards to open data in Denmark although for some specific ministries it is a core task to collect and publish data, as it is for Statistics Denmark under the Danish Ministry for Economic Affairs and the Interior.

(1) Rigsrevisionen. 2019. Extract from Rigsrevisionen's report submitted to the Public Accounts Committee.
https://uk.rigsrevisionen.dk/Media/6/5/12-2018.pdf

(2) Rigsrevisionen. 2019. Beretning om åbne data. https://www.ft.dk/-/media/sites/statsrevisorerne/dokumenter/2018/beretning-12-2018-om-aabne-data.ashx

(3) Digitaliseringsstyrelsen. 2021. Videreanvendelse af offentlige data. https://digst.dk/data/videreanvendelse-af-offentlige-data/

evidence.title: Extract from Rigsrevisionen's report submitted to the Public Accounts Committee

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework establishes a common definition of open data.
The framework promotes open licensing without any restrictions beyond attribution and share-alike.
The framework requires to publish data in machine readable formats.
The rules/guidance requires the use of specific data standards.
The framework promotes training and capacity building among government officials.

indicators.justification:
Regulations provides detailed information on the collection and organization of government budget and spending. These data are published in details - even though information at transaction level is not - by multiple authoritative sources as the Agency for Public Finance and Management and Statistics Denmark. But it has not been possible to find a regulation or law that requires publication or the form of publication. 

(1) Agency for Public Finance and Management, "Public accounts", 2021, https://oes.dk/oekonomi/offentlige-regnskaber/

Summary reports must be provided as structured data.
Expenditure information at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification must be provided as structured data.

The rules/guidance require the approved or enacted budget to be provided as structured data.
The rules/guidance require in-year reports as structured data.
The rules/guidance require year-end reports as structured data.

The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

indicators.justification:
Members of Parliament and Ministers are asked to report economic interests, these declarations of interests are published at the Parliament website and in regards to ministers on a government website. However there is no law or regulation requiring this. For parliamentarians there is no control and no sanctions for not declaring their interest. When a MP doesn't declare his/her economic interests, he/she will appear on a public list of MP's who doesn't follow the guidelines. If a minister doesn't declare his/her economic interests it's for the prime minister to decide if this is acceptable or not.

(1) Folketinget, "Economic interest of MPs", 2021, https://www.ft.dk/da/medlemmer/hverv-og-oekonomiske-interesser

(2) The Government, "CVs and economic interests of ministers", 2021, https://www.regeringen.dk/ministrene/

evidence.title: CVs and economic interests of ministers

The framework requires collecting specific information on assets and liabilities.

The framework requires collecting information on significant changes in assets and liabilities.
The framework requires disclosure of income and assets held by a public official's spouse, family members, or other intimates.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The framework requires the publication of income and asset declarations.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

indicators.justification:
Establishment of a lobby register has been a long time discussion in Denmark. Such a register does still not exists.

(1) Directorate-General for the Presidency, European Parliament, "Transparency of lobbying in Member States - Comparative analysis", 2019: https://www.europarl.europa.eu/EPRS/Lobbying-transparency-comparative-analysis.pdf

evidence.title: Transparency of lobbying in Member States Comparative analysis

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: There is no mention of data or the publication of data in relevant laws, policies, or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework contains clear and unambiguous definitions of lobbyists, lobbying clients, lobbying activities, and public officials.
The framework requires the collection and publication of the identities of lobbyists, lobbyist clients, and public officials who engage with lobbyists.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on lobbyists' goals for lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on timing of lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on topics of lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on how much money is spent on lobbying activities.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

indicators.justification:
Data on campaign and party finance is only sparsely available in Denmark. Political parties are required to publish yearly accounts but with few requirements to the level of details. Donations to political parties can be held anonymous if below a threshold of 20.000 DKK. For donations above this threshold, the name of the donor shall be published but not the exact amount given.



(1) Retsinformation, "Partiregnskabsloven", 2019, https://www.retsinformation.dk/eli/lta/2019/139

(2) Retsinformation, "Partistøtteloven", 2017, https://www.retsinformation.dk/eli/lta/2017/973

(3) Folketinget, "Gruppestøtte og regnskaber", 2021, https://www.ft.dk/da/partier/om-politiske-partier/gruppestoette-og-regnskaber

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: Requirements to publish data are set out in binding policy, regulations, or law.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework contains clear and unambiguous definitions of campaigning activities of parties, candidates, and third parties.

responses.response_text: The framework requires the public disclosure of the identity of any donor who contributes above a defined threshold.
responses.subquestion_text: The framework requires donors' identities be made public.
The framework requires collecting specific information on financial contributions.
The framework requires collecting specific information on assets and liabilities.
The framework requires collecting specific information on income and spending.
The framework requires collecting specific information on in-kind and non-financial support.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The framework requires regular updates, including updates in conjunction with campaigns and defined campaign schedules.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
Consultations on law, regulations and more are published on a dedicated portal: 'Høringsportalen'. At the portal responses to public consultations are published. 
Ministries are required to publish information on public consultation on laws and regulations including the generated response.

(1) Civilstyrelsen, "Høringsportalen", 2021, https://hoeringsportalen.dk/

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: Requirements to publish data are set out in binding policy, regulations, or law.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework requires the publication of notice of intent in advance of public consultation processes.
The framework requires the publication of proposed regulations.
The framework requires the timely publication of a full set of public comments generated through public consultation processes.
The framework requires reasoned responses to be published alongside comments.
The framework requires the publication of final regulations and justification.
The framework requires the publication of challenges to laws and regulations that have undergone public consultation processes, as well as their results.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification: Detailed RTI performance information is not available. Ministry of Justice publishes sparse information of requests but this covers only the ministry itself. The Ombudsmand handles some complaints but doesn't publish structured data on this.

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: There is no mention of data or the publication of data in relevant laws, policies, or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding the number of requests submitted and processed.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding how long it took the relevant government agency or agencies to fill requests.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding material withheld and the reasons for withholding it.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding appeals to RTI determinations and their results.
The framework requires that information is linked to the relevant agency, department, or other governmental entity.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

indicators.justification:
There are examples of companies selling services build on open government data on company ownership and company accounts to support due diligence.

(1) Proff ApS, 2021, https://www.proff.dk/
(2) eStatistik.dk ApS, 2021, https://estatistik.dk/
(3) Danske selskaber, 2021, http://www.danske-selskaber.com/
(4) e-vurdering, 2021, http://www.e-vurdering.dk/

responses.response_text: One or more products/services exist making use of open government datasets, and there is evidence of their widespread use.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used in products/services?
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, government.
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, civil society
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, the private sector.
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, media.
There is evidence that at least one of the examples cited is making use of beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.justification: No evidence found for land data being used to influence policy in the interests of equitable and inclusive land tenure and use

responses.response_text: No evidence of actors or entities using this data to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use?
There is evidence of civil society organizations using data in this way.
There is evidence of media using data in this way.
There is evidence of academics using data in this way.
There is evidence of the private sector using data in this way.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
Is there evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts on land policy?

indicators.justification:
Political integrity data is regularly being referred to in the public debate in Denmark. However not many examples with meaningful positive impacts are found where political integrity data has been used to identify, expose, or highlight failures of government.

(1) Politiken, "Partistøtte", 2021, https://politiken.dk/tag/main/Hemmelig_partist%C3%B8tte

responses.response_text: There are isolated cases of actors or entities using this kind of data for accountability purposes, though the source may not be open data.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used for accountability purposes?
Civil society organizations regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The media regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
Scholars or academic institutions regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The private sector regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.justification:
The procurement practice is party regulated by EU rules. Tenders that qualify as EU tenders are published at the EU tender portal TED. Non-EU tenders are in many cases described at a national portal for tenders.

SKI a not-for-profit organization works to develop better public procurement framework agreements.

(2) Opentender, "Market Analysis - Denmark", 2021, https://opentender.eu/dk/dashboards/market-analysis

(1) SKI, "SKI - Public procurement framework agreements", 2021, https://www.ski.dk/videnssider/facts-about-ski/

(3) Agency for Public Finance and Management, "Økonomistyrelsens analytikerhåndbog", 2021, https://oes.dk/media/38512/oekonomistyrelsens-analytikerhaandbog-v11.pdf

responses.response_text: There is evidence of isolated uses or pilot projects.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent is there evidence of this kind of data use?
There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.
